|Title=Know the main skin tumours
|Description=List the main families of skin tumours (basal cell, squamous cell, melanoma, HPV-induced tumours) and their relative frequency.
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=
|Order=1}}
Malignant skin tumours include tumours of epithelial origin such as basal cell or squamous cell carcinomas, which develop from keratinocytes, and melanoma, which is a malignant melanocytic tumour.

Melanoma is a malignant tumour that develops at the expense of melanocytes (cells that produce melanin).

question.title: What is the origin of melanoma?
question.description: A question about the type of cells that give rise to melanoma

option_a.title: Keratinocytes
option_a.description: A type of skin cell that can give rise to basal cell carcinoma

option_b.title: Melanocytes
option_b.description: The correct answer: melanocytes are the cells that produce melanin

option_c.title: Langerhans cells
option_c.description: A type of immune cell found in the skin, but not directly related to melanin production

option_d.title: Fibroblasts
option_d.description: A type of skin cell involved in wound healing, but not directly related to melanoma development
